titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Asia Society Exhibition files FA258
titlestmt.author: Gail Antos

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-10-17 00:46:02 -0400.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Exhibitions are arranged chronologically. Within each Exhibition, the files are arranged alphabetically, with material in each folder arranged in reverse chronological order. Folder titles, for the most part, reflect the filing system used by the Asia House Gallery staff at the time the files were created.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In late 1959, The Asia Society moved into its new headquarters at Asia House, 112 East 64th Street, New York City. The second floor of the seven-floor building housed two galleries running the width of the house, one in front and one in back - in future, to be known as Asia House Gallery.

On January 7, 1960, the first exhibition to be held at Asia House, "Masterpieces of Asian Art in American Collections", opened to the public. In the Foreword to the catalogue for this exhibition, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, President of The Asia Society, wrote, "It is a source of great pleasure and satisfaction to all of us associated with The Asia Society to be able to present this important collection of Asian art as the first exhibition in our gallery. The assembling of this striking array of art objects, all of them from American collections, will, we hope, prove of value in further appreciation for the artistic achievements of the East."

The Asia Society Exhibition files document the exhibitions held over the next 15 years. From January 1960 through March 1975, a total of 50 exhibitions took place at Asia House. Most were chosen by guest curators who were experts in their particular field. Pieces were loaned by private collectors, by other museums, and on a few occasions, by the governments of the countries whose objects were being displayed. Many of the exhibitions were circulated to other museums throughout North America. Documents concerning lectures and private openings and events, and newspaper and magazine articles about the exhibitions shed further light on the history of Asia House Gallery during this time period.

This collection, although documenting only a small part of The Asia Society's history, provides visible and artistically beautiful examples of how the Society seeks "to further greater understanding and mutual appreciation between the United States and the peoples of Asia." [Source: Catalogue for "Mingei: Folk Arts of Old Japan, 1965]

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Asia Society Exhibition files have undergone standard processing, with material placed in acid free lignin free folders and rehoused in archival manuscript boxes.

The files contain numerous photographs which are an integral and essential part of the collection. Photos have been housed in protective polyester sleeves and remain within the body of the collection.
This collection was processed by Meghan Proehl and Gail Antos, and was completed in 2015.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The material in this collection was originally donated to the Smithsonian Institution's Archives of American Art by the Asia Society on November 12, 1976. Pursuant to the deed of gift, the Archives of American Art had the authority to transfer ownership of these records to the Rockefeller Archive Center, which it did in 2009.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This collection was transferred and donated to the RAC by the Smithsonian Institution's Archives of American Art in 2009.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for researchd. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Archive Center has legal title, copyright and literary property rights to the collection in so far as it holds them.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

did.unittitle: Masterpieces of Asian Art in American Collections

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Objects in the Exhibition were chosen by a committee under the direction of Laurence Sickman, Director of the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery-Atkins Museum, Kansas City, Missouri. Other members of the committee were: Stella Kramrisch, Curator of Indian art, Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; Maurice Dimand, Curator of Near Eastern art, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City (retired); Sherman E. Lee, Director, The Cleveland Museum of Art, Cleveland, Ohio; and Harold F. Stern, Assistant in Japanese art, Freer Gallery, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition was sent to the United States by the Government of Japan to commemmorate the centennial of United States-Japanese diplomatic relations. The Tokyo National Museum, the Society for International Cultural Relations (KBS), Tokyo, and the Japan Society, New York, were sponsors of the Exhibition. Objects in the Exhibition were selected by Mr. Seiroku Noma, Chief Curator of the Tokyo National Museum. Mr. Noma wrote the introduction to the catalogue for the Exhibition.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Objects in the Exhibition were loaned by the Government of Pakistan. Guest director of the Exhibition was Benjamin Rowland, Jr., Acting Curator of Oriental Art, Fogg Museum, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Dr. Rowland prepared the scholarly text for the illustrated catalogue of the Exhibition.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: All the objects in the Exhibition were from the private collection of Mr. Yakichiro Suma of Tokyo, Japan.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhibition were chosen from foremost American collections with additions from England. Guest Director of the Exhibition was Dr. Sherman E. Lee, Director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, Cleveland, Ohio.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition, which was organized, arranged and catalogued by Mr. Henry Trubner, Curator of the Far Eastern Department of the Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Canada, was presented by the Chinese Art Society of America. The Asia Society made their gallery available and contributed to the financing of the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Loan Receipts and Receipts of Delivery
Peasant and Nomad Rugs of Asia

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Guest Director for the Exhibition was Maurice S. Dimand, Curator Emeritus of Near Eastern Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, New York. Dr. Dimand wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition was assembled by George Montgomery, Director of the Asia House Gallery. The catalogue for the Exhibition contains a critical essay by Ad Reinhardt entitled "Angkor and Art", and a partial account by Chou Ta-kuan of his travels to the city of Angkor in 1296 A.D.

did.unittitle: The Art of Southern Sung China

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of sculpture, painting and ceramics from the period of Southern Sung China (1127-1279 A.D.) was chosen by James Cahill, Associate Curator of Chinese Art, Freer Gallery of Art, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., from major American collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of sculpture and painting was assembled by George Montgomery, Director of the Asia House Gallery.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The selection of sculpture in the Exhibition was made by George Montgomery, former Director of the Asia House Gallery, with the assistance of Aschwin Lippe, Associate Curator of Far Eastern Art of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, New York. Mr. Lippe wrote the introductory essay for the catalogue of the Exhibition.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition came to Asia House following its showing earlier in the year at the Fondazione Giorgio Cini of Venice, Italy. The 125 miniatures and manuscripts were all from major American collections. Dr. Ernst J. Grube, Assistant Curator of Near Eastern Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, New York, selected the material for the Exhibition and composed the scholarly catalogue that accompanied it.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition, containing ceramics, paintings, lacquers and the utensils of the Japanese tea ceremony, was organized for Asia House by Sherman E. Lee, Director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, Cleveland, Ohio. Dr. Lee wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: The Evolution of the Buddha Image

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The selection of material for the Exhibition was made by Benjamin Rowland, Jr., of Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Dr. Rowland also wrote the text of the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: Jiro Enjoji and John Rosenfield

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of modern Japanese calligraphy was loaned to the Asia Society by the Japan Society. The material exhibited was brought to the United States for circulation throughout the country by the American Federation of Arts.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The items in the Exhibition were selected by Charles K. Wilkinson, Curator Emeritus of Near Eastern Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, New York. Mr. Wilkinson also wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The material in the Exhibition was selected by Stuart Cary Welch, Lecturer in Fine Arts, the William Hayes Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Mr. Welch also wrote the catalogue of the Exhibition.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of Nepali sculpture, paintings, and manuscripts was selected by Stella Kramrisch, Curator of Indian Art, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and was presented under the patronage of His Majesty, Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva, King of Nepal. Dr. Kramrisch wrote the text for catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Illustrations for Introduction - Copy Negatives and Prints
Correspondence: Request for Contributions to Exhibit: Negative Responses
Photos: Paintings and Manuscripts Not in Exhibition

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of 100 Japanese woodcuts was selected by Margaret Gentles, Associate Curator of Oriental Art, The Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois. Miss Gentles also wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Relics of Ancient China from the Collection of Dr. Paul Singer

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Pieces for the Exhibition were selected by Max Loehr, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Professor of Oriental Art, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, from the extensive private collection of Dr. Paul Singer. Dr. Loehr also wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Mingei: Folk Arts of Old Japan

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Material for the Exhibition was chosen by Hugo Munsterberg, Professor of Art History, New York State University College at New Paltz, New York. Dr. Munsterberg also wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Arts of Japan from the Munsterberg Collection: Annotated Catalogue

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The paintings in the Exhibition were chosen and catalogued by Stuart Cary Welch, Assistant in Islamic Art at the Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, while the catalogue was jointly prepared by Mr. Welch and his colleague, Milo Cleveland Beach, Acting-Curator for the Department of Asiatic Art, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Massachusetts. After its showing at Asia House, the Exhibition subsequently was displayed at The Baltimore Museum of Art, Baltimore, Maryland, and the Munson-Williams-Proctor Institute, Utica, New York.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition, subtitled "Treasures of the Kabul Museum", was presented under the patronage of His Majesty, Mohammed Zaher Shah, King of Afghanistan. Objects for the Exhibition were selected by Benjamin Rowland, Jr., Gleason Professor of Fine Arts, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Dr. Rowland also wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition. After its showing at Asia House, the Exhibition was subsequently displayed in the Lytton Gallery of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Los Angeles, California, and at the National Collection of Fine Arts, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: "Exhibition of Ancient Art of Afghanistan", Japan
Catalogue: "L'Afghanistan Dalla Preistoria All'Islam", Galleria Civica D'Arte Moderna - Torina
Photos: Pictures and Negatives Not in Show
U.S. Travel - Mohammad Karim Barakzai and Ahmad Ali Motamedi

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition titled "7000 Years of Iranian Art" was originally organized and circulated in 1964-1965 by the Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C. At the conclusion of its American tour, the Exhibition, reduced in size to fit the limited spaces of Asia House, was displayed by the Asia Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of approximately 60 bronzes was reassembled from an exhibition previously shown at museums in Cleveland, Ohio, Chicago, Illinois, and Kansas City, Missouri. The catalogue for the Exhibition was published by The Art Institute of Chicago.

did.unittitle: Chinese Art from the Collection of H. M. King Gustaf VI Adolf of Sweden

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition was assembled by Bo Gyllensvrd in cooperation with John Alexander Pope for a tour of American museums organized by the International Exhibitions Foundation, Washington, D.C. Mr. Gyllensvrd, Keeper of the King's Chinese Collection and Director of the Museum of Far Eastern Antiquities, Stockholm, Sweden, and Dr. Pope, Director of the Freer Gallery of Art, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., authored the catelogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Business Arrangements: Annemarie H. Pope
Fantastics and Eccentrics in Chinese Painting

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition, selected by James Cahill, Professor of Oriental Art, University of California, Berkeley, was shown at Asia House in the spring of 1967. It was subsequently exhibited at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in California and at the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum, San Francisco, California. Dr. Cahill wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Packing and Shipping, Insurance, Import License
Japanese Arts of the Heian Period: 794-1185

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhbition were selected by John Rosenfield, Associate Professor, Department of Fine Arts, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Dr. Rosenfield also authored the catalogue. The Exhibition was subsequently shown at Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum.

did.unittitle: Chinese Treasures from the Avery Brundage Collection

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhibition were selected from the Avery Brundage Collection by Ren-Yvon Lefebvre d'Argenc, Director of the Avery Brundage Foundation. Following its showing at Asia House, the Exhibition traveled to museums in Detroit, Michigan; Chicago, Illinois; Honolulu, Hawaii; Seattle, Washington; Portland, Oregon; and San Francisco, California. The catalogue for the Exhibition was authored by Mr. d'Argenc.

did.unittitle: The Art of the Korean Potter

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhibition were selected by Robert P. Griffing, Jr., Curatorial Consultant, Honolulu Academy of Arts, Honolulu, Hawaii. Dr. Griffing wrote the preface to the catalogue for the Exhibition. Following its showing at Asia House, the Exhibition was shown at the Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Canada, and the Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Proofs: Griffing and Field Corrections
"Korean Ceramics: An Art's Variety", Gregory Henderson
"Pottery Production in the Earliest Years of the Yi Period", Gregory Henderson
Ritual Vessels of Bronze Age China

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Professor Max Loehr, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Professor of Oriental Art at Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, selected and catalogued the objects in the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Letters and Notes Regarding Changes
Catalogue: Loehr Manuscript with G. B. Washburn Corrections

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Cleveland Museum of Art presented an Exhibition on the art of the Yan Dynasty in China. The Exhibition contained 306 works assembled by Dr. Sherman E. Lee, the Museum's Director, and Wai-kam Ho, Curator of Oriental Art. Following its showing in Cleveland, the American loans, which comprised about one-third of the Exhibition, traveled to New York and were shown at the Asia House Gallery.

did.unittitle: Yan Art Symposium, Cleveland Museum of Art

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhibition were selected by Pratapaditya Pal, Keeper of the Indian Collections, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Massachusetts. The catalogue for the Exhibition was written by Dr. Pal and included an essay on Tibetan Ritual by Miss Eleanor Olson, Curator of Oriental Art at the Newark Museum, Newark, New Jersey. The Exhibition was shown at the Asia House Gallery and then traveled to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C. and The Seattle Museum, Washington.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: First Galley Proof, Marked Set
Catalogue: Proofs, Corrected, and Four Color Prints
Correspondence: N. Jigme and R. L. Bartholomew
"Mizue: A Monthly Review of the Fine Arts", No. 777, 1969/10
Packing and Shipping: Incoming to Asia House Only
Packing and Shipping: Returns to Lenders

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhibition were selected by Sherman E. Lee, Director of The Cleveland Museum of Art, Cleveland, Ohio. Dr. Lee also authored the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Copy of Manuscript Corrected by Stanislaw Czuma
Catalogue: Copy of Manuscript, Extra, Uncorrected
Catalogue: Manuscript: Copy as Sent to Printer
Catalogue: Marked for Otto Nelson for Slides
Catalogue: Proofs Corrected by Margaret F. Marcus
"Animal Style" Art from East to West

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition was a joint effort of The University Museum of the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and the Asia House Gallery. Material for the Exhibition was chosen by Mrs. Emma C. Bunker, Research Associate of Oriental Art at the Denver Art Museum, Denver, Colorado, Mr. C. Bruce Chatwin of the University of Edinburgh, and Dr. Ann R. Farkas, Assistant Professor, Department of Art History and Archaeology of Colombia University, New York, New York. Following its display at Asia House, the Exhibition traveled to The University Museum of the University of Pennsylvania and to the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum, San Francisco, California.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Manuscript with G. B. Washburn Corrections
Loan List: Farkas Corrections and Chatwin Corrections (Cable only)
Loan Lists, Original: Bunker, Chatwin, Farkas
Masterpieces of Asian Art in American Collections II

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition, to mark the 10th anniversary of the Asia House Gallery, echoed the first Exhibition held at Asia House in 1960. Items for the Exhibition were chosen with the help of the 15 members of the Gallery's Advisory Committee. The catalogue for the Exhibition was designed and edited by Virginia Field, Assistant Director of the Asia House Gallery.

did.unittitle: Packing and Shipping for Returns to Lenders
Slides for G. B. Washburn Lecture
Asian Art: Selections from the Collection of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3rd

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of 70 works of art from the private collection of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3rd was selected and catalogued by Dr. Sherman E. Lee, Director of The Cleveland Museum of Art and its Curator of Oriental Art.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3rd
Bybu: Japanese Screens from New York Collections

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of 26 screens was shown in two sections of 13 screens each in the winter of 1971. Section I was shown from January-February and Section II from February-March. Professor Miyeko Murase, Associate Professor of Art History at Columbia University, New York, New York, chose the works to be included and also write the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Manuscript: Arnold Corrections for Final Version
Catalogue: Manuscript: Final Version, Working Set, Corrections for Printer
Catalogue: Manuscript: G. B. Washburn Corrections
Catalogue: Manuscript: Virginia Field and Arnold Corrections on First Version
Chinese Gold, Silver, and Porcelain from The Kempe Collection

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhibition were selected by Dr. Bo Gyllensvrd, Director of the Museum of Far Eastern Antiquities in Stockholm, Sweden, for circulation by the International Exhibitions Foundation. In addition to its showing at the Asia House Gallery, the Exhibition appeared at several art museums around the United States, including museums in Seattle, Washington, San Francisco, California, Houston and Dallas, Texas, Columbus, Ohio, and Denver, Colorado.

did.unittitle: Ancient Indonesian Art of the Central and Eastern Javanese Periods

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhibition were chosen by Jan Fontein, Curator of Asiatic Art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Massachusetts. The Exhibition marked the first time the Government of Indonesia allowed the nation's treasures to leave the country. Dr. Fontein also authored the catalogue, which was published in both English and Indonesian. The Exhibition was subsequently shown in Kansas City, Missouri, and Los Angeles and San Francisco, California.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: Datus C. Smith Jr.: Finance
Correspondence: Foreign: Ide Anak Agung Gde Agung
Correspondence: J. E. van Lohuizen-de Leeuw
Photos: Indonesian Photos from Pan Am
Photos: Indonesian Photos from Pan Am
Photos: Indonesian Photos from Pan Am
Scholar Painters of Japan: The Nanga School

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The objects in the Exhibition were chosen by James Cahill, Professor of the History of Art at the University of California, Berkeley, and Curator of Oriental Art at the University Museum. The Exhibition was shown in two sections of approximately 35 paintings each: Section I, January 13-February 6, and Section II, February 9-27. Professor Cahill authored the catalogue for the Exhibition. Following its showing at Asia House, the Exhibition traveled to the University Museum in Berkeley, California.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Corrected Copy from Which New Pages Were Typed
Correspondence: Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Burke
From the Bosporus to Samarkand: Flat Woven Rugs

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition opened in May 1969 at The Textile Museum in Washington, D.C., after which it was circulated by the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service. Its final showing was at the Asia House Gallery in the spring of 1972. The catalogue for the Exhibition was written by Anthony N. Landreau and W. R. Pickering and published by The Textile Museum, Washington, D.C.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition, originally scheduled to take place in the spring of 1970 (April-June), was twice postponed (to 1971 April-June and 1972 April-June) and was then postponed indefinitely. Objects for the Exhibition were being selected by Dr. William B. Trousdale, Associate Curator, Department of Anthropology, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition, presented under the patronage of His Majesty King Bhmibok Adulyadej and Her Majesty Queen Sirikit of Thailand, was organized by Professor Theodore Bowie of Indiana University. Prince Subhadradis Diskul, Dean of the Faculty of Archaelogy, Silpakorn University, Bangkok, Thailand, wrote the descriptive entries for the catalogue. Alexander B. Griswold contributed both a learned article to the catalogue as well as notes on the catalogue and plates. The Exhibition traveled to several cities, including Cleveland, Ohio, Bloomington, Indiana, Montreal, Canada, Seattle, Washington, and Dallas, Texas, after it appeared at the Asia House Gallery.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: National Endowment for the Arts
Ceramic Art of Japan: One Hundred Masterpieces from Japanese Collections

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of 100 masterpieces from Japanese collections was organized by Henry Trubner, Curator of Asiatic Art at the Seattle Art Museum, Washington. Following its showing in Seattle, the Exhibition was circulated to several other museums. At Asia House, it was presented in two sections: January 18-February 11 and February 14-March 11. The catalogue for the Exhibition was written and prepared by Mr. Trubner.

did.unittitle: International Symposium on Japanese Ceramics, Seattle Art Museum, 1972 September
A Flower From Every Meadow: Indian Paintings from American Collections

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The works in the Exhibition were chosen by Stuart Cary Welch, Lecturer in the Arts, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Mr. Welch also authored the catalogue. Following its showing at Asia House, the Exhibition was shown at the Center for Asian Art and Culture (Brundage Collection), San Francisco, California, and the Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo, New York.

did.unittitle: Circulation of Exhibition: Buffalo - Albright-Knox Art Gallery
Circulation of Exhibition: San Francisco - Avery Brundage Collection
Shah 'Abbas and the Arts of Isfahan

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition was a joint effort of The Asia Society and Harvard University's Fogg Museum, Cambridge, Massachusetts. The works in the Exhibition were selected by Anthony Welch of the University of Victoria, Victoria, British Colombia, Canada. Professor Welch wrote the catalogue for the Exhibition.

did.unittitle: Catalogue: Copy of Manuscript Sent to Printer
National Endowment for the Arts Grant Application
The Colors of Ink: Chinese Paintings and Related Ceramics from the Cleveland Museum of Art

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition featured works from the Cleveland Museum's collection, chosen for display at Asia House by Serman E. Lee, Director of the Museum. Dr. Lee also authored the catalogue.

did.unittitle: Rjsthn Temple Hangings of the Kisha Cult

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition from the collection of Karl Mann was organized by the American Federation of Arts. The catalogue for the Exhibition was authored by Robert Skelton of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London and was available through the American Federation of Arts.

did.unittitle: The Poet-Painters: Buson and His Followers

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition was organized by Calvin French of the University of Michigan Department of the History of Art.

did.unittitle: Asian Art: Part II: Selections from the Collection of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3rd

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exhibition of 70 pieces was chosen by Sherman E. Lee, Director of the Cleveland Museum of Art. Dr. Lee also authored the catalogue for the Exhibition.
